member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.Answered
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines if the message has been answered.

remarks.p: Returns true if the current message has been answered (server-side flag \Answered). This property is controlled by the developer, not the server (ie. the server does not decide when a message has been answered).
When setting this property the Imap component will send a STORE command to the server to update the flags of the message.

member.value: If the message's Answered flag is set, this property returns true; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.Flagged
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines if the message has been flagged.

remarks.p: Returns true if the current message has been flagged for urgent or special attention (server-side flag \Flagged). This property is controlled by the developer, not the server (ie. the server does not decide when messages deserve attention).
When setting this property the Imap component will send a STORE command to the server to update the flags of the message.

member.value: If the message's Flagged flag is set, this property returns true; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.Draft
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines if the message is a draft.

remarks.p: Returns true if the current message has an incomplete composition (server-side flag \Draft). This property is controlled by the developer, not the server (ie. the server does not decide when composition is complete).
When setting this property the Imap component will send a STORE command to the server to update the flags of the message.

member.value: If the message's Draft flag is set, this property returns true; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.Recent
member.summary: Gets a value which determines if the message is recent.

remarks.p: Returns true if the current message has arrived recently in the mailbox (server-side flag \Recent). This property is controlled by the server, not the developer, and the definition of "recent" may vary according to server implementation.

member.value: If the message's Recent flag is set, this property returns true; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.Seen
member.summary: Gets or sets a value which determines if the message has been seen.

remarks.p: Returns true if the current message has been read (server-side flag \Seen). This property is controlled both by the developer and the server. The server changes this flag in response to the IMAP FETCH command, but it can be changed by the developer as well.
When setting this property the Imap component will send a STORE command to the server to update the flags of the message.

member.value: If the message's Seen flag is set, this property returns true; otherise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage.InternalDate
member.summary: Returns the internal date of the message.

remarks.p: Returns the internal date property of the message as tracked by the server, indicating when the server received the message.

The internal date is assigned by the server upon receipt of the message. This is not to be confused with the date header of the message itself, which typically indicates the date the message was sent.

member.value: A string representation of the messages internal date.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageCollection
member.summary: Contains ImapMessage objects.

remarks.p: The ImapMessageCollection class is used to contain ImapMessage objects which are located in the same mailbox. Since this collection is representing server-side objects, using the methods of this class causes IMAP commands to be sent to the server. For example, ImapMessageCollection.Add causes an "APPEND" command to be sent.

member.summary: Add a new message with customized attributes to the mailbox using APPEND.

remarks.p: Using the ImapMessageCollection.Add method causes an APPEND command to be sent to the IMAP server, adding the message contained in message to the mailbox represented by Imap.CurrentMailbox. Typically, message will be a MessageStream object, but can be any Stream object. flags determines which flags are set on the new message. internalDate sets the internal date (the date the message arrived) of the message on the server.

A System.Datetime representing the internal date to use for the message.
member.returns: An ImapMessage object representing the newly added message.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageCollection.IndexOf(Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage)
member.summary: Searches for the specified value and returns the zero-based index of the first occurrence within the entire collection.

remarks.p: The collection is searched forward starting at the first element and ending at the last element.
This method performs a linear search. On average, this is an O(n/2) operation, where n is Count. The longest search is an O(n) operation.
This method determines equality by calling Object.Equals.

member.returns: The zero-based index of the first occurrence of value within the entire collection, if found; otherwise, -1.
member.param: The Object to locate in the collection.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageCollection.Contains(Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessage)
member.summary: Determines whether an element is in the collection.

remarks.p: This method performs a linear search; therefore, the average execution time is proportional to Count. That is, this method is an O(n) operation, where n is Count.
This method determines equality by calling Object.Equals.

member.param: The Object to locate in the collection. The element to locate can be a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.returns: true if item is found in the collection; otherwise, false.

member.exception:
Index is less than zero.
-or-
Index is equal to or greater than Count.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.EndEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for asynchronous completion events.

remarks.p: The EndEventArgs.Exception property returns any Exception which occurred during the asynchronous operation. The EndEventArgs.Stats property returns any object passed in to the accompanying BeginXXX method.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.EndEventArgs.Exception
member.summary: Gets any exception which occurred during the asynchronous operation.

remarks.p: Check this property to tell if an exception occurred during the asynchronous operation. If this property is null, no exception occurred.

The exception property is useful for checking exceptions and handling them appropriately. For example, if a bad command was sent to the server, a ProtocolException may be thrown. You could check this property to see if it was of type ProtocolException, than handle appropriately.

member.value: If any exception occurred during the asynchronous operation, this property will contain an Exception object describing the exception.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.EndEventArgs.State
member.summary: Gets the object that was included as part of the associated method call.

remarks.p: The EndEventArgs.State property can be used in the calling asynchronous method to make data accessible to the handling event.

This property is useful for making data accessible to the handling event. Since asynchronous methods are "disconnected" (meaning that when one is called, it executes on it's own and returns in the event handler) data that you were using in the code that called the asynchronous method may not be available in the event handler. Simply pass this data in as state when calling the asynchronous method (usually a BeginXXX method) and it is available in the event handler. If you do not wish to make an object accessible in the EndXXX event, simple pass in null as state.

member.value: An object containing data passed into the calling asynchronous method.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapProgressEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the Imap.Progress event.

remarks.p: This class provides data for the Imap.Progress event, which is raised periodically while a message or message section is being transferred. The ImapProgressEventArgs.Message property represents the actual message being transferred.
The value of ImapProgressEventArgs.Length and ImapProgressEventArgs.Position depends on the operation. For example:

ul.li: If downloading headers, ImapProgressEventArgs.Length is the total length of the headers. ImapProgressEventArgs.Position is the count of bytes received.
If downloading messages, ImapProgressEventArgs.Length is the total length of the message. ImapProgressEventArgs.Position is the count of bytes received.
If downloading bodystructure or envelope, both of these values will be 0, because the total amount of data beging retrieved is unknown.

If downloading messages, ImapProgressEventArgs.Length is the total length of the message. ImapProgressEventArgs.Position is the count of bytes received.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapProgressEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method (event handler) that will be raised when progress information is available.

remarks.p: As Microsoft describes in their MSDN documentation, the event model in the .NET Framework is based on having an event delegate that connects an event with its handler. To raise an event, two elements are needed:

ul.li: A class that holds the event data. This class must derive from the base class EventArgs.
A delegate that points to a method that provides the response to the event.

remarks.p: When asynchronously getting messages, the class that holds the event data is the ImapProgressEventArgs class. A method must be created with the same signature as the delegate. If you are working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, this can be automatically done for you. See the Using Events In PowerTCP topic for more information. If you are not working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, you must do this yourself. In this example that would mean a method would have to be defined to accept two arguments (an object and an ImapProgressEventArgs) and return void. Once this has been done, the delegate must be "connected" to the handling event. This is done by adding an instance of the delegate to the event. For more information about event handler delegates, see the Using Events In PowerTCP topic.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the Imap events: Imap.Alert, Imap.EndClear, Imap.EndCopy, Imap.EndExamine, Imap.EndInvoke, Imap.EndLogin, Imap.EndLogout, Imap.EndMailboxRemove, Imap.EndNoop, Imap.EndPurge, Imap.EndRefresh, Imap.EndSet, Imap.EndSubscribe, Imap.EndSubscribe, Imap.LineReceived, Imap.Update.

remarks.p: This class provides event data for any event that handles a response from the IMAP server. This event could be a reporting-type event (such as the Imap.LineReceived event, which is raised on each line received) or a process completed event (such as any of the EndXXX events listed above, which are raised upon completion of the associated BeginXXX method).

If multiple responses are expected, these responses will be part of the ImapResponseEventArgs.Responses property. ImapResponseEventArgs.Response will reflect the first response. For this reason, ImapResponseEventArgs.Response will always equal Responses[0].

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect Status responses.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method (event handler) that will be raised when a response is received from an IMAP server.

remarks.p: As Microsoft describes in their MSDN documentation, the event model in the .NET Framework is based on having an event delegate that connects an event with its handler. To raise an event, two elements are needed:

ul.li: A class that holds the event data. This class must derive from the base class EventArgs.
A delegate that points to a method that provides the response to the event.

remarks.p: When asynchronously getting messages, the class that holds the event data is the ImapResponseEventArgs class. A method must be created with the same signature as the delegate. If you are working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, this can be automatically done for you. See the Using Events In PowerTCP topic for more information. If you are not working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, you must do this yourself. In this example that would mean a method would have to be defined to accept two arguments (an object and an ImapResponseEventArgs) and return void. Once this has been done, the delegate must be "connected" to the handling event. This is done by adding an instance of the delegate to the event. For more information about event handler delegates, see the Using Events In PowerTCP topic.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the Imap.EndMailboxAdd, Imap.EndList, and Imap.Mailbox events.

remarks.p: This class provides data for any event which markes the completion or progress of any asynchronous method which manipulates or gathers information about IMAP mailboxes.

If multiple mailboxes are effected, these mailboxes will be part of the MailboxEventArgs.Mailboxes property. MailboxEventArgs.Mailbox will reflect the first mailbox effected. For this reason, MailBoxEventArgs.Mailbox will always equal MailboxEventArgs.Mailboxes[0].

If any error occurred during the asynchronous operation, it would be returned in the EndEventArgs.Exception property. Be sure to check this property first before accessing other members of MailBoxEventArgs.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates asynchronously creating a new mailbox.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxEventArgs.Mailbox
member.summary: Gets the Mailbox object representing the IMAP mailbox for which the event was raised.

remarks.p: If accessing this property from within the Imap.EndMailboxAdd event (notifying completion of the MailboxCollection.BeginAdd method), then this property returns the Mailbox object representing the newly created mailbox. If accessing this property from within the Imap.Mailbox event (notifying new mailbox data was received from the server) then this property returns the Mailbox object representing the mailbox for which new data was received.

member.value: The Mailbox object representing the mailbox.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates asynchronously creating a new mailbox.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method (event handler) that will be raised when mailbox information is available or an asynchronous method involving mailbox manipulation completes.

remarks.p: As Microsoft describes in their MSDN documentation, the event model in the .NET Framework is based on having an event delegate that connects an event with its handler. To raise an event, two elements are needed:

ul.li: A class that holds the event data. This class must derive from the base class EventArgs.
A delegate that points to a method that provides the response to the event.

remarks.p: When asynchronously getting messages, the class that holds the event data is the MailboxEventArgs class. A method must be created with the same signature as the delegate. If you are working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, this can be automatically done for you. See the Using Events In PowerTCP topic for more information. If you are not working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, you must do this yourself. In this example that would mean a method would have to be defined to accept two arguments (an object and an MailboxEventArgs) and return void. Once this has been done, the delegate must be "connected" to the handling event. This is done by adding an instance of the delegate to the event. For more information about event handler delegates, see the Using Events In PowerTCP topic.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MessagePartEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the Imap.EndGetPart event.

remarks.p: This class provides data for the Imap.EndGetPart event, which is raised upon completion of the ImapMessage.BeginGetPart method. The ImapMessage.BeginGetPart method is used to get message parts (such as attachments) from the IMAP server. The message part is accessable via the MessagePartEvent.Part property. The ImapMessage that contains the part is accessble via the MessagePartEvent.Message property.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates asynchronously retrieving a part of a message.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.summary: Gets the ImapMessage that contains the part.

remarks.p: The MessagePartEventArgs.Message property returns the ImapMessage object representing the message that contains the part for which this event was raised.

member.value: An ImapMessage object.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MessagePartEventArgs.Part
member.summary: Gets the part retrieved.

remarks.p: The MessagePartEventArgs.Part property returns a System.IO.Stream object containing the part data. Cast this value into the appropriate stream type. For example, if an attachment was retrieved, you would cast MessagePartEventArgs.Part into a MimeAttachmentStream object.

member.value: A System.IO.Stream object containing part data.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the Imap events: Imap.EndGetMessage, Imap.EndMessageAdd, Imap.EndSearch.

remarks.p: This class provides event data for any event that handles the completion of any method which asynchronously retrieves messages, adds messages, or searches for messages.

ImapMessageEventArgs.Message will always contain a value. If multiple messages were involved, ImapMessageEventArgs.Messages will contain a value for each message. ImapResponseEventArgs.Message will always equal Messages[0].

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the Mailbox.BeginSearch method. This example constructs the search "SEARCH FLAGGED SINCE 1-Feb-1994 NOT FROM 'Smith'"
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageEventArgs.Message
member.summary: Gets an ImapMessage object representing the message for which the event was raised.

remarks.p: The ImapResponseEventArgs.Message property returns the first message (Messages[0]). If a multiple messages are effected, use the ImapMessageEventArgs.Messages property.

member.value: Returns an ImapMessage object representing the message.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the Mailbox.BeginSearch method. This example constructs the search "SEARCH FLAGGED SINCE 1-Feb-1994 NOT FROM 'Smith'"

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageEventArgs.Messages
member.summary: Gets an array of ImapMessage objects representing all messages effected by the asynchronous method.

remarks.p: If multiple messages were effected by the asynchronous method (ex. using Mailbox.BeginSearch to search for multiple messages), iterate through this collection to access each message. If a single message was from the server (ex. using Mailbox.BeginAdd to append a single message), access Messages[0] or simply access the ImapMessageEventArgs.Message property, which contains the first message effected.

member.value: Returns an array of ImapMessage objects representing the message.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseType
member.summary: Contains the types of responses returned by an IMAP server.

remarks.p: The ImapResponseType enumeration indicates the type of response received from the server. This value is exposed through the ImapResponse.ResponseType property.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect Status responses.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseType.Continuation
member.summary: 0 The server expects the client to send additional data. This is not an error, but just a step in a data transfer process for certain commands.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseType.Data
member.summary: 1 The response includes data that is sent in response to a command that is being executed (ex. a response to a LIST command).

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseType.Raw
member.summary: 2 The server is returning raw information (ex. the contents of a message).

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponseType.Status
member.summary: 3 The server is indicating the status of a currently executing command. The ImapResponse.Status property indicates the value of that status.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus
member.summary: Contains the values of status codes defined by IMAP.

remarks.p: The ImapStatus enumeration indicates the status of a response from the IMAP server. Not all responses provide status. Typically, status responses come at the completion of a command execution. Whether an ImapResponse object contains status information is indicated by the ImapResponse.ResponseType property, in which case it will return ImapResponseType.Status. The status itself is exposed by the ImapResponse.Status property of the ImapResponse object.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates sending a NOOP command and checking the response.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.None
member.summary: 0 No status information was returned.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.Ok
member.summary: 1 Success. Indicates a successful command completion. Otherwise, this response is informative. Success can vary in meaning depending on the command executed. For example, a COPY operation (Mailbox.Copy) will return an OK response even when no messages could be copied. Review the behavior of the operation in question for further details.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.No
member.summary: 2 Failure. Indicates a unsuccessful command completion. Otherwise, this response is considered a warning.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.Bad
member.summary: 3 Error. Indicates that the command was not properly formed (ex. the command syntax was incorrect). Otherwise, this response is considered a protocol-level error or server failure.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.PreAuth
member.summary: 4 Preauthorization. Through some external mechanism, authentication has occurred without a login, and no login command is necessary.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapStatus.Bye
member.summary: 5 Shutdown. Indicates the server is about to close the connection to the client. This can occur during logout, inactivity, or as a server warning.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode
member.summary: Represents the response codes defined by IMAP.

remarks.p: Enumerated type used to represent the response code returned by the IMAP server with a line of data. Response codes are optional and contain additional information beyond the status information.
This enumeration is used by the ImapResponse.Code property of the ImapResponse object. For example, if the response from the server is
then ImapResponse.Code will be ImapCode.UidValidity.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect UIDVALIDITY codes.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.None
member.summary: 0 No response code was provided.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.Alert
member.summary: 1 The response contains an alert which must be shown to the user. This also causes the Imap.Alert event to be raised.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.BadCharset
member.summary: 2 The response denotes a SEARCH operation failed due to an unsupported charset.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.Capability
member.summary: 3 The response contains a list of IMAP server capabilities. This type of response is also used to populate the Imap.Capabilities collection.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.NewName
member.summary: 4 The response denotes an operation failed because the Mailbox was renamed.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.Parse
member.summary: 5 The response denotes an error occurred during the parsing of message headers.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.PermanentFlags
member.summary: 6 The response contains a list of all flags that can be changed permanently within the mailbox and its messages. Any flags not on this list should not be set. A value of \* means new, non-standard flags can be created.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.ReadOnly
member.summary: 7 The response denotes the selected mailbox is read-only.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.ReadWrite
member.summary: 8 The response denotes the selected mailbox is read-write.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.TryCreate
member.summary: 9 The response denotes an executing command failed because the target mailbox does not exist. This response code is returned as a hint to the client that the target mailbox should perhaps be created prior to issuing the command that failed.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.UidNext
member.summary: 10 The response includes the UIDNEXT value for the selected mailbox, indicating what the UID of the next created message will be.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.UidValidity
member.summary: 11 The response includes the UIDVALIDITY value for the selected mailbox. This value can be used in combination with message UIDs to identify messages uniquely between sessions.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCode.Unseen
member.summary: 12 The response code of the response includes the number (position id) of the first unseen message in the selected mailbox.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections
member.summary: Represents the sections of an IMAP message when partial messages are retrieved.

remarks.p: The ImapMessageSections enumeration represents the sections of an IMAP message. IMAP allows partial message retrieval, and this enumeration (whose values are additive) is used to indicate what sections of the message should be retrieved. One or more values from this enumeration can be passed to the Get method of either the ImapMessage and Mailbox objects.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates retrieving partial messages.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Body
member.summary: 1 Retrieve the entire message.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.BodyStructure
member.summary: 2 Retrieve the parsed structure of the body of the message. This is used in the ImapMessage.GetOutline method to retrieve the outline of the message without its content.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Envelope
member.summary: 4 Retrieve the message header, formatted in an IMAP specific fashion.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Flags
member.summary: 8 Retrieve the message flags (ex. Answered, Delete, etc.).

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Date
member.summary: 16 Retrieve the internal date of the message, indicating when it was received by the server.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Header
member.summary: 32 Retrieve the headers for the message.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Size
member.summary: 64 Retrieve the length of the encoded message, in bytes.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Text
member.summary: 128 Retrieve the text of the message, if applicable.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapMessageSections.Uid
member.summary: 256 Retrieve the unique ID (UID) of the message.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlagModifier
member.summary: Represents the method used when modifying flags.

remarks.p: The ImapFlagModifier enumeration represents the method used when modifying flags on the server. This type is used when calling the Mailbox.Set command to update one or more flags on messages, and it is used in combination with the ImapFlags enumeration.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the Set method to change message flags.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlagModifier.Add
member.summary: 1 Adds the specified flags to the message.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlagModifier.Remove
member.summary: 2 Removes the specified flags from the message.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlagModifier.Replace
member.summary: 3 Replace the specified flags on the message.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags
member.summary: Represents the flags defined by IMAP.

remarks.p: The ImapFlags enumeration represents the flags defined by IMAP. These flags can be used with the Mailbox.Set command to update message flags on the server. These same server flags can be manipulated using the properties of the ImapMessage object (ex. Mailbox.Set command specifying an add of ImapFlags.Delete is equivalent to setting the ImapMessage.Delete property = true), although the use of Mailbox.Set command is more efficient for message groups.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the Set method to change message flags.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.None
member.summary: 0 No flags. This is used when a Set is being performed with ImapFlagModifier.Replace to clear all flags from a message.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Answered
member.summary: 1 Indicates that a message has been replied to. This flag is managed entirely by the IMAP client.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Deleted
member.summary: 2 Indicates that a message should be deleted when the next EXPUNGE operation occurs. This flag is managed entirely by the IMAP client, but it is used by the IMAP server during an EXPUNGE operation.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Draft
member.summary: 4 Indicates that the composition of a message has not been finished. This flag is managed entirely by the IMAP client.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Flagged
member.summary: 8 Indicates that a message has been marked for special attention. This flag is managed entirely by the IMAP client.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Recent
member.summary: 16 Indicates that a message has arrived at the server since the last update. This flag is managed entirely by the IMAP server.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapFlags.Seen
member.summary: 32 Indicates that a message has been read. This flag is managed both by the IMAP client and the IMAP server. Clients can update the flag, but the server does as well based on FETCH operations that occur.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse
member.summary: Represents a single line response from an IMAP server.

remarks.P: The ImapResponse class represents a single line response from an IMAP server. A response from an IMAP server may be received as a reply to a command, or may be received unprovoked. Individual fields of the response are parsed into properties of the ImapResponse class. Whenever a response is received from the server, the data is parsed into an ImapResponse object and the Imap.LineReceived event is raised to allow the user access to the information. This built-in response parsing makes Imap.LineReceived superior to Imap.Trace when the user is interested in the contents of the response.
remarks.p: For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the properties of this object would be as follows:

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.ToString
member.summary: Returns the entire response line.

remarks.p: This method returns the entire response line as it was received from the server.

member.returns: A string representation of the entire response line.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Status
member.summary: Gets the status of the response.

remarks.p: The ImapResponse.Status property contains an ImapStatus value indicating the status of a response from the IMAP server. Not all responses provide status. Typically, status responses come at the completion of a command execution. Whether an ImapResponse object contains status information is indicated by the ImapResponse.ResponseType property, in which case it will return ImapResponseType.Status.
For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.Status property would contain ImapStatus.Ok. This information is not included with all responses from the server.

member.value: If status was included with the response, this property will return an ImapStatus value describing the status. If no status was included with the response, this property will return ImapStatus.None.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates sending a NOOP command and checking the response.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.ResponseType
member.summary: Gets the type of the response.

remarks.p: This property returns the type of the response sent by the server (ImapResponseType.Status, ImapResponseType.Continuation, ImapResponseType.Data, or ImapResponseType.Raw). All responses fall into one of these four types. For example, if the server was transferring a message, this property would be ImapResponseType.Raw.

member.value: An ImapResponseType representing the type of response.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect Status responses.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Code
member.summary: Gets the response code.

remarks.p: This property returns the response code of the line. Codes are optional and contain additional information for the client beyond the status level and are provided so the user can take additional action upon the information contained in the code. For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.Code property would contain ImapCode.UidValidity. This information is not included with all responses from the server.
See the ImapCode enumeration for possible code values.

member.value: If a code was included with the response, this property will contain an ImapCode value describing the code received. If no code was included with the response, this property will contain ImapCode.None.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect UIDVALIDITY codes.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Explanation
member.summary: Gets any explanation text returned by the server.

remarks.p: This property returns any text sent by the server as additional explanatory information. For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.Explanation property would contain "UIDs valid". This information is not included with all responses from the server.

member.value: If an explanation was included with the response, this property will contain the string representation of that explanation. If no explanation was included with the response, this property will contain an empty string.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect Status responses.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Tag
member.summary: Gets the unique identifier for the command.

remarks.p: This property returns the unique identifier found on tagged responses to commands. This unique identifier is actually generated by the Imap component when sending a command. The IMAP server will return this identifier with the response associated with the original client command.
For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.Tag property would contain "A2", which was also the tag used when the client sent the original "CAPABILITY" command.

member.value: A string representation of the tag used to identify the response.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Value
member.summary: Gets the text returned by the server as the first value/token of the response.

remarks.p: This property returns the text returned by the server as the first value/token related to this response. For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.Value property would contain "99". This information is not included with all responses from the server.

member.value: The text indicating the value if returned; otherwise an empty string.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect values of RECENT and EXISTS responses.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.CodeValue
member.summary: Gets any additional text returned with the response code.

remarks.p: This property returns any additional text returned with the response code. This additional text is optional even if a response code is received. Typically, this additional text will contain the "value" for the code specified in the response code.
For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
the ImapResponse.CodeValue property would contain "1032904889". This information is not included with all responses from the server.

member.value: If a code value was included with the response, this property will contain the string representation of that code value. If no code value was included with the response, this property will contain an empty string.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the LineReceived event to detect UIDVALIDITY codes.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapResponse.Operation
member.summary: Gets any text returned by the server indicating the action of the response.

remarks.p: This property returns any text returned by the server indicating the action associated with this response. For example, if the following line was received from the IMAP server,
remarks.pre: * CAPABILITY IMAP4 IMAP4rev1 AUTH=CRAM-MD5 AUTH=PLAIN AUTH=LOGIN
remarks.p: the ImapResponse.Operation property would contain "CAPABILITY". This information is not included with all responses from the server.

member.value: The text indicating the action if returned; otherwise an empty string.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion
member.summary: Details the search criterion which modifies the IMAP SEARCH command.

remarks.p: The ImapCriterion enumeration specifies types of search restrictions when using the Mailbox.Search method. Use this enumeration with the ImapSearchParameter class, to create custom searches of messages on the IMAP server.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.All
member.summary: Search for all messages (no restrictions). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Answered
member.summary: Search for all answered messages (messages that have the Answered flag set). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Bcc
member.summary: Search for messages that contain the specified string in the BCC field of the message envelope.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Before
member.summary: Search for messages with internal date that occurs before the specified date.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Body
member.summary: Search for messages that contain the specified string in the message body.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Cc
member.summary: Search for messages that contain the specified string in the CC field of the message envelope.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Deleted
member.summary: Search for deleted messages (messages that have the Deleted flag set). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Draft
member.summary: Search for draft messages (messages that have the Draft flag set). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Flagged
member.summary: Search for flagged messages (messages that have the Flagged flag set). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.From
member.summary: Search for messages that contain the specified string in the FROM field of the message envelope.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Header
member.summary: Search for messages that contain the specified string in the message header. Note that the format requires that the header field be specified, so the parameter value for this search criterion should be "<header> <value>".

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Keyword
member.summary: Search for messages that have the specified keyword flag set. This allows for searches based on custom flag types.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Larger
member.summary: Search for messages larger than the specified byte count.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.New
member.summary: Search for all recent and unseen messages (messages with the Recent flag set but not the Seen flag). No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Not
member.summary: Perform a logical inversion (NOT operation) on another search criterion. No search parameter is required if this is part of a collection of ImapSearchParameters and another search criterion follows this one; otherwise, a search parameter is required.

member.summary: Search for messages that do not have the Flagged flag set. No search parameter is required.

member.summary: Search for messages that do not have the specified keyword flag set. This allows for searches based on custom flag types.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.NotSeen
member.summary: Search for messages that do not have the Seen flag set. No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Old
member.summary: Search for messages that do not have the Recent flag set. No search parameter is required.

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.On
member.summary: Search for messages that have an internal date that exactly matches the value specified (disregarding time).

member.name: F:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapCriterion.Or
member.summary: Perform a logical OR operation on the two search criterion that follow this one. This search parameter must be followed by two other search parameters; these will represent the conditions to be ORed.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapSearchParameter
member.summary: Represents a search parameter used with the MailBox.Search method.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Search method sends the "SEARCH" command to the server along with all of the search restrictions specified ImapSearchParameter. Proper use involves creating an object which implements ICollection, adding several ImapSearchParameters to this object, and passing this object into the Mailbox.Search method. Multiple values are combined with a logical AND. Other logical combinations can be represented using the ImapCriterion values ImapCriterion.Not and ImapCriterion.Or.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.ImapUTF7Encoding
member.summary: Represents a modified UTF-7 encoding of Unicode characters to be used for IMAP mailbox names.

remarks.p: RFC 2060 describes a modified UTF-7 encoding to use for IMAP mailbox names, as standard UTF-7 encoding causes some conflict with certain characters within the IMAP protocol (see the RFC, section 5.1.3 for a list of conflicts).
The PowerTCP Imap component uses this class to automatically manage mailbox name encoding/decoding.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Response
member.summary: Presents the response portion from an Internet protocol Request/Response pair.

remarks.p: Often, protocols define that commands be responded to with responses made up of a response code and response text. For example(using the FTP protocol as an example), the FTP protocol defines a command "CWD" which is a request to change the working directory. If command sent to the server was "CWD MYDIR" (a request to change to a directory called "MYDIR"), the response back from the server may be something like "200 Working Directory Changed". In PowerTCP this response is encapsulated by the Response object, allowing access to the code (through the Response.Code property), the text (through the Response.Text property), or the raw response (through the Response.ToString method). The Response object is usually a member of the Invoke object, which represents a request/response pair.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates closing a connection.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Response.ToString
member.summary: Returns the complete response string received.
member.returns: A string representing the unparsed response from the server.

remarks.p: The String.ToString method is overridden to allow access to the entire unparsed string. To retrieve a parsed listing of the response code or text, use the Response.Code or Response.Text property, respectively.
This property is useful if you wish to see the entire response string returned from the server without any formatting applied.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Response.Code
member.summary: Gets the 3-digit response code from the response string.
member.value: An integer representing the response code parsed from the raw response.

remarks.p: The Response.Code property allows easy access to the code parsed from the raw response. To retrieve the raw response, simply use the Response.ToString method.
This property is useful because it allows checking of the code received from the server without parsing. For example, if you are checking for a response code between 200 and 299, you can simply say:
This is helpful because you don't have to explicitly parse the raw response, and because the value is already an integer, allowing numerical comparison.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Response.Text
member.summary: Gets the textual response without the 3-digit response code and CR/LF's.
member.value: A string representing the test response parsed from the raw response.

remarks.p: The Response.Text property allows easy access to the text (the response from the server minus the response code and CRLFs) parsed from the raw response. To retrieve the raw response, simply use the Response.ToString method.
This property is useful because it allows access to the response string from the server without having to parse.
If the response from the server was "200 Working Directory Changed", this property would contain "Working Directory Changed".

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Invoke
member.summary: Presents the results from an Internet protocol Request/Response pair.

remarks.p: Many Internet protocols are based on a request/reply system, where the client sends a request, and the server sends at least one reply. This continues lock-step until communication is complete. The Invoke object encapsulates these request/reply pairs.

In PowerTCP commands are often sent using the Object.Invoke or Object.BeginInvoke methods. When a command is sent an Invoke object is returned describing both the request and response. The response is encapsulated by the Invoke.Response property, which allows easy access to the raw and parsed response from the server. The request is represented by the Invoke.Request property, a string containing the request sent.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.InvokeEventArgs
member.summary: This class is passed into EndInvoke events and provides data for these event.

remarks.p: A InvokeEventArgs object is passed into an EndInvoke event after a command has been sent asynchronously. This object represents the command sent to the server and the response received from the server.

Many TCP/IP protocols are based on a request/response system, where the client sends a request, and the server sends at least one reply. This continues lock-step until communication is finished. The InvokeEventArgs object encapsulates these request/reply pairs.

In PowerTCP commands are often explicitly sent using the Object.Invoke or Object.BeginInvoke methods, and transparently sent using higher-level methods. When a command is sent asynchronously an InvokeEventArgs object is returned in the event handler describing both the request and response. The response is encapsulated by the InvokeEventArgs.Response property which allows easy access to the raw and parsed response from the server. The request is represented by the InvokeEventArgs.Request property, a string containing the request sent.

If your code causes an exception, it would be returned to the handling event without you seeing it. To preclude such a condition, you should ALWAYS use a try/catch block around your event-handling code.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.InvokeEventArgs.State
member.summary: Gets the object that was included as part of the associated method call.

remarks.p: The EndEventArgs.State property can be used in the calling asynchronous method to make data accessible to the handling event.

This property is useful for making data accessible to the handling event. Since asynchronous methods are "disconnected" (meaning that when one is called, it executes on it's own and returns in the event handler) data that you were using in the code that called the asynchronous method may not be available in the event handler. Simply pass this data in as state when calling the asynchronous method (usually a BeginXXX method) and it is available in the event handler. If you do not wish to make an object accessible in the EndXXX event, simple pass in null as state.

member.value: An object containing data passed into the calling asynchronous method.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.InvokeEventArgs.Exception
member.summary: Gets any exception which occurred during the asynchronous operation.

remarks.p: Check this property to tell if an exception occurred during the asynchronous operation. If this property is null, no exception occurred.

The exception property is useful for checking exceptions and handling them appropriately. For example, if a bad command was sent to the server, a ProtocolException may be thrown. You could check this property to see if it was of type ProtocolException, than handle appropriately.

member.value: If any exception occurred during the asynchronous operation, this property will contain an Exception object describing the exception.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.InvokeEventHandler
member.summary: Represents the method (event handler) that will be raised when the Object.BeginInvoke operation completes.
member.param: The source of the event.
An InvokeEventArgs object that contains the event data.

remarks.p:
As Microsoft describes in their MSDN documentation, the event model in the .NET Framework is based on having an event delegate that connects an event with its handler. To raise an event, two elements are needed:
A class that holds the event data. This class must derive from the base class EventArgs.
A delegate that points to a method that provides the response to the event.
When using the Object.BeginInvoke method, the class that holds the event data is the InvokeEventArgs class. A method must be created with the same signature as the delegate. If you are working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, this can be automatically done for you. See the "Using Events In PowerTCP" topic for more information. If you are not working within the Visual Studio.NET environment, you must do this yourself. In this example that would mean a method would have to be defined to accept two arguments (an object and a InvokeEventArgs) and return void. Once this has been done, the delegate must be "connected" to the handling event. This is done by adding an instance of the delegate to the event (see examples below).
For more information about event handler delegates, see the "Using Events In PowerTCP" topic.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailAddress
member.summary: The MailAddress object represents a single email address.

remarks.p: When using PowerTCP, email addresses are represented by MailAddress objects. MailAddress objects are created by passing an email address into the MailAddress constructor. This can be done one of two ways:

li.p: Pass in the email address only.

This will create a MailAddress object and populate the MailAddress.Address, MailAddress.Domain, and MailAddress.User properties. The MailAddress.Friendly property will be an empty string, and will have to be explicitly set.
Pass in the email and friendly address.
li.code: MailAddress m = new MailAddress("\"Bob Test\" me@myserver.com");
li.p: This will create a MailAddress object and populate the MailAddress.Address, MailAddress.Domain, MailAddress.Friendly, and MailAddress.User properties.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailAddresses
member.summary: A collection of MailAddress objects.

remarks.p: The MailAddresses class represents a collection of MailAddress objects. To add a MailAddress to the MailAddresses collection either pass the strings representing the email addresses into the MailAddresses constructor, or use one of the MailAddresses.Add methods. Other advanced functionality of the MailAddresses object include MailAddresses.RemoveDuplicates, which automatically removes any duplicat addresses, MailAddresses.Verify, which verifies the validity of addresses, and MailAddresses.SplitByDomain, which returns multiple MailAddresses (contained in an ArrayList) containing addresses with the same domain.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailAddresses.Verify(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Attempts to verify the vailidity of addresses comained within the MailAddresses collection by doing a DNS lookup.
member.param: Comma-delimited list of DNS servers to use for verification.
Specifies the amount of time to wait for a response to a query to a DNS server.

remarks.p: This method attempts to verify the validity of all MailAddress objects in the MailAddresses collection. When this method is called, the MailAddress.ServerResponse property is set from the response from the server. The MailAddress.ServerResponse property is a Response object which encapsulates the response from the server. To see if verification succeeded or failed, check the Response.Code and Response.Text properties. If verification succeeded, the response will be formatted as "hostnameCRLFdot.add.res.s". If verification did not succeed, the ServerResponse property will return null, so be sure to always check for null before accessing the properties of ServerResponse.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox
member.summary: Represents an IMAP mailbox on the server.

remarks.p: Mailbox objects correspond to mailboxes existing on the server. This information is reliably updated when initially entering the Mailbox. All other changes may not be definitive, as other clients can be making changes to the same account. While a mailbox is selected (see Imap.CurrentMailbox), the information will be reliably updated based on notifications from the server (in response to commands or unsolicited updates while in the Idle state).

Since this object is representing a server-side object, using properties or methods of this class may cause an IMAP command to be sent to the server to update the mailbox. For example, setting Mailbox.Name would cause a RENAME command to be sent to the server to rename the mailbox.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Dispose
member.summary: Releases all resources associated with the object.

remarks.p: The Object.Dispose method abruptly aborts the connection and releases all resources.

Object.Dispose should ONLY be used to release all resources used by the object, and the object should not be used subsequently. If an abort is desired, then Object.Close or Object.Connection.Close if available should be used to terminate activity and reset the object. The Object cannot be used once Object.Dispose() or Object.Dispose(true) are called.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.CompareTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns:
A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the comparands. The return value has these meanings:
Value Meaning
Less than zero This instance is less than obj.
Zero This instance is equal to obj.
Greater than zero This instance is greater than obj.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Delete
member.summary: Removes the specified mailbox from the server.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Delete method removes the specified mailbox from the server. Use of this method causes an IMAP DELETE command to be sent to the server to delete the mailbox and causes an implicit destruction of the object, with Mailbox.Dispose called upon successful completion of the operation, rendering the Mailbox unusable. The Mailbox is also removed from the MailboxCollection it is a member of.
See also MailboxCollection.Remove.

member.returns: An ImapResponse object encapsulating the response from the server.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.
Object reference not set to an instance of an object

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.BeginDelete(System.Object)
member.summary: Begins to asynchronously remove the specified mailbox from the server.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.BeginDelete method begins to asynchronously remove the specified mailbox from the server. Use of this method causes an IMAP DELETE command to be sent to the server to delete the mailbox and causes an implicit destruction of the object, with Mailbox.Dispose called upon successful completion of the operation, rendering the Mailbox unusable. The Mailbox is also removed from the MailboxCollection it is a member of.
The Imap.EndMailboxRemove event is raised upon completion of this method.
See also MailboxCollection.BeginRemove.

member.param: User state information.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.
BeginXXX method used without providing an EndXXX event handler.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Refresh
member.summary: Updates all of the mailbox properties to reflect the server version.

remarks.p: Any time a method is called to add/delete/modify a mailbox, the command is sent to the server to update the server mailbox and the appropriate modifications are made to the local Mailbox object representing the server mailbox. The Mailbox.Refresh method updates all the Mailbox properties to reflect the server version. This method uses the IMAP EXAMINE or REFRESH commands to retrieve the current settings of the mailbox, so calling this method is equivalent to setting the mailbox equal to the current mailbox (i.e. this Mailbox object will be the Imap.CurrentMailbox property after calling this method). In addition, this will get information about any new mailbox updates that may have occurred due to another user being logged into the account.

member.returns: An ImapResponse object encapsulating the response from the server.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.BeginRefresh(System.Object)
member.summary: Begins to asynchronously update all of the mailbox properties to reflect the server version.

remarks.p: Any time a method is called to add/delete/modify a mailbox, the command is sent to the server to update the server mailbox and the appropriate modifications are made to the local Mailbox object representing the server mailbox. The Mailbox.BeginRefresh method updates all the Mailbox properties to reflect the server version. Upon completion of this operation, the Imap.EndRefresh event is raised. This method uses the IMAP EXAMINE or REFRESH commands to retrieve the current settings of the mailbox, so calling this method is equivalent to setting the mailbox equal to the current mailbox (i.e. this Mailbox object will be the Imap.CurrentMailbox property after calling this method). In addition, this will get information about any new mailbox updates that may have occurred due to another user being logged into the account.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Purge
member.summary: Deletes all messages marked for deletion.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Purge method deletes all messages marked for deletion (messages with the \Delete flag set, also with ImapMessage.Delete = true). This method uses the IMAP EXPUNGE command to delete all the marked messages . If you have Imap.AutoPurge set to true there is no need to explicitly call Mailbox.Purge as the messages will automatically be expunged.

member.returns: An ImapResponse object encapsulating the response from the server.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.BeginPurge method deletes all messages marked for deletion (messages with the \Delete flag set, also with ImapMessage.Delete = true). Upon completion of this operation, the Imap.EndPurge event is raised. This method uses the IMAP EXPUNGE command to delete all the marked messages . If you have Imap.AutoPurge set to true there is no need to explicitly call Mailbox.Purge as the messages will automatically be expunged.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Get
member.summary: Retrieves all of the messages contained in the mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Get method retrieves in full the messages contained in this mailbox and uses the data to populate the Mailbox.Messages collection and its contents.
This method uses the IMAP FETCH command to retrieve message content. The command uses the UIDs of the messages (ImapMessage.Uid) to retrieve content.
This method is useful for bulk operations. If you would like to retrieve only a single message, use the ImapMessage.Get method of the ImapMessage object.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Search(System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Search for messages within a mailbox based on criteria.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Search method sends the "SEARCH" command to the server along with all of the search restrictions specified ImapSearchParameter. Proper use involves creating an object which implements ICollection, adding several ImapSearchParameters to this object, and passing this object into the Mailbox.Search method as criteria. Multiple values are combined with a logical AND. Other logical combinations can be represented using the ImapCriterion values ImapCriterion.Not and ImapCriterion.Or.

member.returns: An array of ImapMessage objects which meet the criteria specified by criteria.
member.param: A collection of one or more ImapSearchParameter objects, defining the type of search to perform.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.
Specified cast is invalid

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates using the Mailbox.Search method. This example constructs the search "SEARCH FLAGGED SINCE 1-Feb-1994 NOT FROM 'Smith'"
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.FullName
member.summary: Gets or sets the full path name of the mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.FullName property gets or sets the full path name of this mailbox. For example, with a mailbox named:
the Mailbox name-related properties would be as follows:

When setting the Mailbox.Fullname property, a RENAME command is sent to the server. If you are renaming a Mailbox within the same mailbox use the Mailbox.Name property instead. For example, if you wanted to rename
to
you could simply set Mailbox.Name to "bobjohnson". However, if you wanted to rename
to
you could not do this by setting Mailbox.Name. You would have to set Mailbox.FullName to "archive/bobbackup".
The equivalent asynchronous method for renaming a mailbox is
"&" is represented when sent as "&-". Anything between an "&" and a "" is converted to Unicode.

member.value: A string representing the full path name of the mailbox.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the "short" name of the mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Name property gets or sets the "short" name of this mailbox, meaning the text part of the name between the last occurrence of the delimiter (Imap.Delimiter) (if any) and the end of the string. For example, with a mailbox named:
the Mailbox name-related properties would be as follows:
When setting the Mailbox.Name property, a RENAME command is sent to the server. This will only rename the "short" name, which has some limitations. For example, if you wanted to rename
to
you could simply set Mailbox.Name to "bobjohnson". However, if you wanted to rename
to
you could not do this by setting Mailbox.Name. You would have to set Mailbox.FullName to "archive/bobbackup".
The equivalent asynchronous method for renaming a mailbox is
"&" is represented when sent as "&-". Anything between an "&" and a "" is converted to Unicode.

member.value: A string representing the "short" name of the mailbox.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Recent
member.summary: Gets the count of messages that are recent in this Mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Recent property returns the number of messages that are recent in this mailbox. Typically, a server will consider a message to be "recent" if the current session is the first session to be notified about the messages arrival.

member.value: The count of recent messages in this mailbox.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.FirstUnseen
member.summary: Gets the ID of the first unseen message in the mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.FirstUnseen property returns the ID (accessable via the ImapMessage.Id property of the ImapMessage object) of the first unseen message in the inbox.
If you wish to access this message directly simply convert the 1-based server collection to the 0-based messages collection by subtracting 1, i.e.
remarks.pre: // Access the first unseen message (be sure to check that this isn't 0 first) Mailbox.Messages[Mailbox.FirstUnseen - 1];
remarks.p: If no message is unseen, this property will return 0.

member.value: The ID of the first unseen message.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Messages
member.summary: Gets a collection which contains all messages in the mailbox.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Messages property returns the ImapMessageCollection object containing ImapMessage objects representing each message in this mailbox. This collection will not be populated with messages upon first access. You must first call Mailbox.Refresh for this collection to have any items.

member.value: An ImapMessageCollection which contains all messages in the mailbox.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates retrieving partial messages.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.ReadOnly
member.summary: Gets a value which determines if the mailbox is read-only.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.ReadOnly property returns true if the mailbox is read-only. This could be the case either because of the way that the mailbox was selected (ex., EXAMINE was used instead of SELECT), or because it is configured in a read-only fashion.

member.value: true if the mailbox cannot be written to; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Selectable
member.summary: Gets a value which detemines if the mailbox can be selected.

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Selectable property determines if the mailbox can be selected. If false, then this mailbox cannot be Imap.CurrentMailbox.

member.value: true if the mailbox can be selected; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.SublevelsAllowed
member.summary: Gets a value which determines if mailboxes can be created as sublevels below this mailbox.

remarks.p: If this property is false, any attempts to create mailboxes as children of this mailbox will result in an error.

member.value: true if additional mailboxes can be creates as sublevels in the heirarchy below this mailbox; otherwise false.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Marked
member.summary: Gets a value which determines if the mailbox has been "marked".

remarks.p: The Mailbox.Marked property returns true if the mailbox has been "marked" as interesting by the server. Typically, this might occur because the mailbox contains new messages.

member.value: true if the mailbox has been "marked" by the server; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets an object reference that can be used to associate this instance with any other.
member.remarks: Use this property to associate any type derived from Object class with the component. A common use for the Tag property is to store data that is closely associated with the component.
member.value: Any object that is associated with the component; null if no objects are associated with the component.

member.value: Any object that is associated with the object, null if no objects are associated with the object

member.name: P:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox.Mailboxes
member.summary: Gets a collection which contains all mailboxes in the mailbox.

remarks.p: Returns the MailboxCollection object containing mailboxes below this mailbox in the hierarchy. This is dynamically generated the first time it is accessed.

member.value: A MailboxCollection which contains all messages in the mailbox.

member.name: T:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection
member.summary: Represents a collection of Mailbox objects.

remarks.p: The MailboxCollection class contains only Mailbox objects that exist on an IMAP server. It is used to represent either the results of an Imap.List method call (as the Imap.Mailboxes property), or as the collection of child mailboxes to a given mailbox (Mailbox.Mailboxes).

The MailboxCollection class can be manipulated by using the Mailbox.Add, Mailbox.Remove, and Mailbox.Refresh methods. Since this is a server-side collection, calling these methods sends the associated IMAP command to the server. For example, calling MailboxCollection.Remove results in a DELETE command being sent to the server to actually delete the mailbox. If any method called results in the addition, deletion, or modification of a mailbox, the MailboxCollection will be automatically updated to reflect this.
Typically, the Mailbox objects representing mailboxes contained within this collection are dynamically generated the first time the collection is accessed.

example.p: [Visual Basic, C#] The following example demonstrates appending mailboxes to the server.
[C++, JScript] No example is available for C++ or JScript. To view a Visual Basic or C# example, click the Language Filter button in the upper-left corner of the page.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.Add(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new mailbox to the server.

remarks.p: The MailboxCollection.Add method creates a new mailbox on the server using the specified name by sending the IMAP CREATE command. name will be used to create the mailbox "within" the currently selected mailbox by adding name to the parent mailboxes name. If there is no parent of this mailbox, then the new mailbox will be a top-level mailbox.
After calling this method, the MailboxCollection will be automatically updated to reflect the current state of the collection. There is no need to explicitly call MailboxCollection.Refresh.

member.returns: A Mailbox object representing the newly added mailbox.
member.param: The name of the newly created mailbox.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.
Attempt to illegally modify a server-side collection.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.BeginAdd(System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Begins to asynchronously add a new mailbox to the server.

remarks.p: The MailboxCollection.BeginAdd method begins to asynchronously create a new mailbox on the server using the specified name by sending the IMAP CREATE command. When complete, the Imap.EndMailboxAdd event is raised. name will be used to create the mailbox "within" the currently selected mailbox by adding name to the parent mailboxes name. If there is no parent of this mailbox, then the new mailbox will be a top-level mailbox.
After calling this method, the MailboxCollection will be automatically updated to reflect the current state of the collection. There is no need to explicitly call MailboxCollection.Refresh.

member.param: The name of the newly created mailbox.
User state information.
member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.

BeginXXX method used without providing an EndXXX event handler
--or--Attempt to illegally modify a server-side collection.
member.returns: An IAsyncResult that represents the asynchronous operation, which could still be pending.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.Refresh
member.summary: Refreshes the list of mailboxes represented by this collection.

remarks.p: The MailboxCollection.Refresh method refreshes the list of mailboxes represented by this collection. This could be either the list of top-level mailboxes or a set of child mailboxes.

If the contents of the MailboxCollection are modified by using the methods of the MailboxCollection the collection will be automatically refreshed. MailboxCollection.Refresh would typically only be used to refresh the collection if two users are using the same mail account simultaneously.

member.exception: Bad IMAP protocol response received from server.
The requested address is not valid in its context.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.BeginRefresh(System.Object)
member.summary: Begins to asynchronously refresh the list of mailboxes represented by this collection.

remarks.p: The MailboxCollection.BeginRefresh method begins to asynchronously refresh the list of mailboxes represented by this collection. This could be either the list of top-level mailboxes or a set of child mailboxes. Upon completion, the Imap.EndMailboxRefresh event will be raised.

If the contents of the MailboxCollection are modified by using the methods of the MailboxCollection the collection will be automatically refreshed. MailboxCollection.BeginRefresh would typically only be used to refresh the collection if two users are using the same mail account simultaneously.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.IndexOf(Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox)
member.summary: Searches for the specified value and returns the zero-based index of the first occurrence within the entire collection.

remarks.p: The collection is searched forward starting at the first element and ending at the last element.
This method performs a linear search. On average, this is an O(n/2) operation, where n is Count. The longest search is an O(n) operation.
This method determines equality by calling Object.Equals.

member.returns: The zero-based index of the first occurrence of value within the entire collection, if found; otherwise, -1.
member.param: The Object to locate in the collection.

member.name: M:Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.MailboxCollection.Contains(Dart.PowerTCP.Mail.Mailbox)
member.summary: Determines whether an element is in the collection.

remarks.p: This method performs a linear search; therefore, the average execution time is proportional to Count. That is, this method is an O(n) operation, where n is Count.
This method determines equality by calling Object.Equals.

member.param: The Object to locate in the collection. The element to locate can be a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.returns: true if item is found in the collection; otherwise, false.
